title.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire-PEPFAR Fund

description.narrative: The goal of Cote d'Ivoire PEPFAR funding is to initiate a data revolution to achieve greater transparency, mutual accountability and local impact in Sub-Saharan Africa. The program will seek to attempt to address some of the root causes of insufficient data use for decision-making around HIV/AIDS, broader health, gender equality, and economic growth.

title.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire-Compact

description.narrative: The MCC Board of Directors approved a $524.7 million compact for Cote d'Ivoire at its quarterly board meeting in September 2017. The Government of Cote d'Ivoire is expected to contribute an additional $22 million to support the compact. The program will support the country's drive to diversify its economy through investments in the education and transportation sectors. The Projects respond to constraints to economic growth in Cote d'Ivoire, and the Government's national priorities by seeking to address education and the competitiveness of Abidjan as the country's economic growth hub by improving the mobility of goods and people.

In addition, MCA-C�te d�Ivoire agrees to maintain and implement the ESMS throughout the life of the Compact and through up to 90 days of the closure period including retaining sufficient technical resources and budget to operate the ESMS in form and substance satisfactory to MCC.

MCA-C�te d�Ivoire must maintain the ESOC in form and substance satisfactory to MCC through the Compact Term and up to 90 days of the Compact closure period.

title.narrative: EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR EMPLOYABILITY PROJECT

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR EMPLOYABILITY PROJECT: The Skills for Employability and Productivity Project will increase access to secondary education and teacher training, and support the construction of up to 84 new secondary schools. Through a public-private partnership, a new technical vocational education and training (TVET) model will advance development of in-demand skills. It will also help the government mitigate gender disparities, improving outcomes for girls in the education system.

title.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire Compact Key Performance Indicators

condition.narrative: Further details on conditions precedent affecting this activity can be found in the top-level parent activities.

Prior to Disbursement for construction of secondary schools under the Equitable Access Sub-Activity in the second tranche in Gb�k�, the Government must have (a) adopted the new Gender Policy under the Gender Policy Sub-Activity, (b) established a Gender Unit with an adopted staffing model, (c) incorporated the Gender Unit into the Ministry of National Education organizational chart, (d) established a budget line item in the Ministry of National Education�s budget to support the Gender Unit�s activities, and (e) allocated the funding necessary for the operationalization, functioning and sustainability of the Gender Unit for that current fiscal year.

Prior to the Disbursement of Program Funding for the construction of secondary schools under the Equitable Access Sub-Activity after 18 months after entry into force of the Compact, the Ministry of National Education must have provisionally deployed inspecteurs to Gb�k� and San Pedro and provided those inspecteurs with adequate operational budgets to conduct supportive supervision of teachers in those regions, which budget should cover vehicle operations and maintenance.

Prior to the Disbursement of Program Funding for the construction of secondary schools under the Equitable Access Sub-Activity after 24 months after entry into force of the Compact, the Parties agree to perform an interim performance review of progress on school construction during the Compact, and consider whether any modifications or other changes to the Activity are necessary.

description.narrative: Level Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, this indicator will be reported for the first time in year 5 (July 23 to June 24) of the Compact. According to the "Skills high level WorkPlan 02062024 / Planning tranche 1 02.06.2024", the first CDPs will be completed in august 2024 and data for this indicator will be available in early 2025 through the school statistics produced by the DESPS/MENA.

title.narrative: Promotion rates for students in Compact-supported lower-secondary schools in Gb�k�

description.narrative: Level Outcome of This indicator is not expected to be reported on in the ITT. According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, this indicator should be reported for the first time in to year 5 (July 23 to June 24) of the Compact, after the first CDPs have been completed and opened long enough for students to advance to the next grade level. According to the "Skills high level WorkPlan 02062024 / Planning tranche 1 02.06.2024", the first CDPs will be completed in august 2024 and the first data for this indicator would be available in early 2026 through DESPS statistics. It is therefore likely that this indicator will not be collected before the end date of the Compact.

title.narrative: Students benefitting from improved teacher training

description.narrative: Level Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, this indicator will be reported for the first time in year 6 (July 24 to august 25) of the Compact. The student teachers trained on the new curriculum completed their training in July 2024. MCA is working with the ENS to have the list of trained teachers. It is likely that this list will be available in Q22. MCA C�te d'Ivoire will then work with MENA to identify the schools to which each teacher is assigned and the best methodology to collect data related to this indicator. Data for this indicator will likely be available for Q23

description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, this indicator will be reported for the first time in year 5 (July 23 to June 24) of the Compact. Data will be available the first time student enrollment is collected (which typically takes place mid-school year) after the first CDPs have been completed and opened. According to the "Skills high level WorkPlan 02062024 / Planning tranche 1 02.06.2024", the first CDPs will be completed in august 2024 and data for this indicator will be available in early 2025 through the school statistics produced by the DESPS/MENA.

title.narrative: Dropout rate of students in Compact-supported TVET centers

description.narrative: Level Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start during year 5 of the compact, following completion of the construction of the TVET centers. The construction of the first two TVET centers has begun. According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI center for industrial professions started in February 2024 and is expected to be completed in June 2025. The construction of the CMTL center for transport and logistics professions began in April 2024 and is expected to be completed in July 2025. Based on that timeline, the first two TVET centers are projected to enroll the first cohorts for training in September 2025. Thus, when taking into account the definition of this indicator and the fact that it is an annual indicator, the earliest that reporting could be reasonably expected would be summer 2026, which is approximately one year after the Compact End Date. Thus, data to inform this indicator will not be available until well after the end date of the Compact.

title.narrative: Employed graduates of MCC-supported education activities

description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start during year 5 of the compact, following completion of the construction of the TVET centers. The construction of the TVET centres began in February 2024 (CFPMI centre for industrial professions) and in April 2024 (CMTL centre for transport and logistics professions). According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI is expected to be completed in June 2025 and the CMTL center in July 2025. Based on these timelines, the first two TVET centers are projected to enroll the first cohorts for training in September 2025. Thus, when taking into account the definition of this indicator, the earliest that reporting could be reasonably expected would be the first half of 2027. Thus, data to inform this indicator will not be available until well after the end date of the Compact.

comment.narrative: According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start during year 5 of the compact, following completion of the construction of the TVET centers. The construction of the TVET centres began in February 2024 (CFPMI centre for industrial professions) and in April 2024 (CMTL centre for transport and logistics professions). According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI is expected to be completed in June 2025 and the CMTL center in July 2025. Based on these timelines, the first two TVET centers are projected to enroll the first cohorts for training in September 2025. Thus, when taking into account the definition of this indicator, the earliest that reporting could be reasonably expected would be the first half of 2027. Thus, data to inform this indicator will not be available until well after the end date of the Compact. Baseline

title.narrative: Graduates from MCC-supported education activities

description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start during year 5 of the compact, following the completion of the construction of the TVET centers. The construction of the first two TVET centers has begun. According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI center for industrial professions started in February 2024 and is expected to be completed in June 2025. The construction of the CMTL center for transport and logistics professions began in April 2024 and is expected to be completed in July 2025. Based on that timeline, the first two TVET centers are projected to enroll the first cohorts for training in September 2025. In order to be counted under this indicator, an individual must complete all relevant coursework, successfully complete the certification exam, and receive a graduation certificate. Thus, the earliest that reporting on this indicator could be reasonably expected would be summer 2026, approximately one year after the Compact End Date.

description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start during year 5 of the compact, following completion of the construction of the TVET centers. The construction of the first two TVET centers has begun. According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI center for industrial professions started in February 2024 and is expected to be completed in June 2025. The construction of the CMTL center for transport and logistics professions began in April 2024 and is expected to be completed in July 2025. Based on that timeline, the first two TVET centers are projected to enroll the first cohorts for training in September 2025. Thus, the earliest that reporting on this indicator could reasonably occur based on the indicator definition is late 2025, which is after the Compact End Date but may fall within the Compact Closure Period.

title.narrative: TVET accreditation obtained for Compact-supported TVET centers

description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start during year 5 of the compact, following completion of the construction of the TVET centers. The construction of the first two TVET centers has begun. According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI center for industrial professions started in February 2024 and is expected to be completed in June 2025. The construction of the CMTL center for transport and logistics professions began in April 2024 and is expected to be completed in July 2025. Based on that timeline, the first two TVET centers are projected to enroll the first cohorts for training in September 2025. The MCA and MCC project teams no longer expect the Compact-supported TVET center to obtain accreditation prior to the Compact End Date (CED). Thus, the target for this indicator will not be met by CED.

title.narrative: COGES created and functional

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, this indicator will be reported for the first time in year 5 (July 23 to June 24) of the Compact, after the completion of the construction and equipment works for the first CDPs, when the COGES has been created, trained with the community mobilization firm, and held their first official meeting. According to the "Skills high level WorkPlan 02062024 / Planning tranche 1 02.06.2024", the first CDPs will be opened in September 2024. The first data for this indicator will be available after the opening of the first CDPs (i.e. October - December 2024).

title.narrative: Compact-supported Integrated Educational Management Information System (EMIS) improvements deployed

description.narrative: Date Output of According to annex II of the monitoring and evaluation plan of March 2023, version N�2, this indicator will first be reported during year 5 (July-23 to June-24) of the Compact. The deployment of EMIS improvements will take place after the recruitment of the Consultant for the establishment and operationalization of EMIS-ENIA. To date, the GROUPE DEFIS ET STRATEGIES has been recruited for the implementation of the EMIS since July 26, 2023 and organized its kick off meeting on August 17, 2023. According to the "Skills high level WorkPlan 02062024 / Planning Soft 02.06.2024", the final tests of the modules' good functioning will be completed in October 2024. So this indicator is likely to be collected during the quarter October - December 2024.

title.narrative: Date on which reformed supervision tools are developed and validated

description.narrative: Date Output of According to Annex II of the March 2023 monitoring and evaluation plan, version N�2, this indicator would be available in February 2024 (Q19) but there is a delay in that validation process due to the fact that there have been several discussions between all stakeholders to finalize the supervision tools. The final tool test report is available. For the next step, the curriculum must be validated by the MENA who will then take a memorandum to formalize its use after the generalization workshop on tools in October 2024. MCA will work with MENA and plan to populate this data during next quarter Q22

title.narrative: Educational facilities constructed or rehabilitated

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of According to Annex II of the March 2023 monitoring and evaluation plan, version N�2, this indicator should have been reported for the first time in year 4 (July 22 to June 23) of the Compact. To date, the 2 construction companies have been recruited for the construction of the ENS of San Pedro (MYKA company selected in August 2023 and has started construction in october 2023) and the ENS of Bouak� (EMEBCI company selected in October 2023 and has started construction in december 2023). According to the "Skills high level WorkPlan 02062024 / Planning TVET & ENS 02.06.2024 ", construction of the teacher training centers should be completed (including all furniture, equipment, utility connections and other resources) in april 2025 (ENS- San Pedro) and may 2025 (ENS-Bouak�).

title.narrative: Gender Unit budget received

description.narrative: Level Output of For reasons of understanding the definition of the indicator, work was done with the Department of Budget which shared with MCA a document giving some explanations on the interpretation of variables in the budget file used to inform the indicator. At the end of this work, the data source is the document"SITUATION EXECUTION BUDGET DEEG 2022 2023" at the column "CP Actuel". CP Actuel is the budget to date. It shall take into account, where appropriate, all the changes resulting from the various budgetary acts which have been made to the initial budget. Therefore, data has been updated via a HACR for Q10 and Q18.

title.narrative: Gender Unit operationalized

description.narrative:
Date Output of This indicator is considered complete and is not expected to be updated further.
To date, the Gender Unit is operational according to the definition provided in Annex 1 of the M&E Plan V1 December 2019. They are:
1. Adoption of the National Gender Policy in Education (completed): The final gender policy document was validated by all MCA, MENETFP and ANO stakeholders of MCC in April 2020. The final document was presented by the MENETFP at the Council of Ministers and was adopted on December 9, 2020. It was prefaced and signed (see date and signature of� Document Politique Genre MENETFP Pr�fac�e_V�, � Attestation CCM Politique Genre � 2. Creation of the DEEG (Completed)
3. Incorporation into the organization chart of the Ministry of Education (Completed): The Department of Equality, Equity and Gender (DEEG) was created and incorporated into the organization chart of MENETFP.
4. Appropriate staffing in accordance with approved staffing plan (Completed): The Staffing plan received NO from MCC on December 1, 2019 and in accordance with this staffing plan DEEG staff have been put in place. The MCA-CI received the service orders from the members of the staff of the DEEG in accordance with phase 1 of the staffing Plan
5. Allocation of funding necessary for the operation and sustainability of the Gender Unit (Completed): The MEETFP shared Order No. 0103 of June 29, 2020 on the creation of an economic activity and credit transfer which indicates on pages 3 and 4 that the DEEG has a budget of 20,000,000 FCFA, for the year 2020

title.narrative: Lower-secondary schools substantially completed

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, this indicator will be reported for the first time in year 5 (July 23 to June 24) of the Compact, when the construction completion certificates for the CDPs have been signed and delivered in accordance with construction contract documents, so that classrooms and facilities can be used for their intended purpose (i.e. at least 80% of construction completed). According to the "Skills high level WorkPlan 02062024 / Planning tranche 1 02.06.2024", the first CDPs will be completed in august 2024. The provisional reception mission for the first 5 CDPs was organized in July-August 2024. The provisional reception reports are currently being prepared. It is likely that this indicator will be collected in October-December 2024 (Q22).

title.narrative: National Assessment framework for lower-secondary schools developed

description.narrative:
Date Output of This indicator is considered complete and is not expected to be updated further.
The National Assessment Framework have been validated in August 2023 by MENA. After that, it took time to finalize the document (formatting, correction of mistakes, editing, etc.) but the final version of the document was released in June 2024. The report did not provide a specific date of validation, we considered the last day of the month as the date of validation
The National Assessment Framework lays the foundations of the assessment system in C�te d'Ivoire and takes into account classroom assessments, standardized national examinations, national and international assessments of learning outcomes, as well as learning assessments in literacy and non-formal education to measure and improve student and learner outcomes.

title.narrative: National Assessments for lower-secondary schools implemented

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of The final report of the national assessment of student learning is available this quater (July 2024). This assessment provides reliable data on the performance of 5th and 3rd grade students in French and mathematics. The report did not provide a specific date of validation, we considered the last day of the month as the date of validation.

title.narrative: Number of catchment areas where gender priority action items have been implemented

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of Last quarter, for the indicator �Number of catchment areas where gender priority action items have been implemented,� MCC requested that MCA M&E develop a report template to serve as the primary data source with sufficient detail to verify that the indicator is being reported according to the M&E Plan definition. To be in compliance with this request, the MCA M&E worked with the MCA GSI team and the AETS consultant to review the data collection tool, the quality of data for this indicator and collect data for year 2023. The gender priority actions are implemented by the consulting firm AETS. Three missions are considered for this indicator. Mission 2A aims to raise awareness among customary and religious authorities, local authorities and parents of students about gender equality and equity in education. It includes the following tasks: (1) the identification of a pool of trainers in the two regions (Gb�k� and San Pedro), (2) the training of trainers, (3) the provision of equipment to trainers, (4) the development of a communication or awareness-raising plan, (5) the organization of talks-debates or restitutions with leaders, (6) the production and broadcasting of radio programs at the regional level, (7) raising awareness among local authorities, the judicial administration and the local police. Mission 5A aims to promote the involvement of women's associations in the life of the school. These main tasks are: (1) the preparation of a report on the state of play of the situation of women's groups, (2) the creation and support of women's groups. Mission 8A aims to increase the participation of learners in formal secondary education through the following tasks: (1) the preparation of an inventory report on the learning conditions of students in the last grade of primary school in informal schools and areas with the highest secondary school losses, (2) the provision of furniture (tables, benches, etc.), (3) the provision of school and teaching kits for students in the last class of primary schools in informal schools and (4) the number of supported learners transferred from the last year of primary school in the informal to the first year of secondary school in the CDP. The implementation of the priority actions began in January 2023. As of December 31, 2023, No catchment area has received all the priority actions intended to be implemented. However, missions 2A and 5A have been completed in 13 catchment areas, including 4 in the San Pedro region (Adjam�n�, Oueoulo, Man� and Youwasso) and 9 in Gb�k� (Bendekouassikro, Ti�pl�, Mamini, Krofouinssou, Sinzekro, Akadiafoue, Belakro, Golibl�nou and Kanangopkli). Mission 8A has not yet been completed in any catchment area. Tasks 2 and 3 of this mission are likely to be implemented during the Q23 quarter.

title.narrative: Percentage of relevant positions that are occupied by a staff member trained in EMIS

description.narrative: Level Output of According to Annex II of the March 2023 M&E Plan, version N�2, this indicator will first be reported during year 5 (July-23 to June-24) of the Compact. To date, the GROUPE DEFIS ET STRATEGIES has been recruited for the implementation of the EMIS since July 26, 2023 and organized its kick off meeting on August 17, 2023. The consultant's service will take place in 02 phases: (i) first phase from August 09, 2023 to August 08, 2024: Development of the 05 modules; (ii) second phase: from August 09, 2024 to August 2025 will be the commissioning and user support phase. The updating of the system, after the pilot will be made in this second phase as well as all the capacity building activities. Data collection for this indicator is expected to start during the quarter October - December 2024.

title.narrative: Educational facilities constructed or rehabilitated

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of According to Annex II of the Monitoring and Evaluation Plan of March 2023, version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start during year 5 of the compact, following completion of the construction of the TVET centers. The construction of the first two TVET centers has begun. According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI center for industrial professions started in February 2024 and is expected to be completed in June 2025. The construction of the CMTL center for transport and logistics professions began in April 2024 and is expected to be completed in July 2025. In order to be considered fully constructed and ready to receive students, a TVET center must not only have completed major works but also be equipped, have all utilities connected, and comply with relevant MCC and national policies regarding safety and security. Thus, reporting on this indicator would not be expected until the final quarter of the Compact at the earliest.

title.narrative: Feedback loop system established

description.narrative: Date Output of According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the two TVET centers are expected to be completed in July 2025 at the latest. Annex 22 of the PDC agreement signed with each consortium indicates that the private partner will set up an information and management system at least 03 months prior to the opening of the TVET center and ensure the operation of the system. Thus, reporting on this indicator is expected in the final quarter of the Compact.

title.narrative: Tracer studies conducted in Compact-supported TVET centers

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of According to Annex II of the March 2023 Monitoring and Evaluation Plan, Version N�2, reporting on this indicator was expected to start in year 5 of the compact.The construction of the first two TVET centers has begun. According to the service orders for the start of construction sent to the construction firms, the construction of the CFPMI center for industrial professions started in February 2024 and is expected to be completed in June 2025. The construction of the CMTL center for transport and logistics professions began in April 2024 and is expected to be completed in July 2025. Based on that timeline, the first two TVET centers are projected to enroll the first cohorts for training in September 2025. Thus, when taking into account the definition of this indicator and the fact that it is an annual indicator, the earliest that reporting could be reasonably expected for this indicator would be the first half of 2027, which is after the Compact End Date. As such, the end of compact target will not be met.

title.narrative: Tracer studies system developed

description.narrative: Date Output of According to Annex II of the M&E Plan, the tracer studies system was expected to be developed by year 4 of the Compact. To date (Q21), the tracer system has now been developed since June 2024 by the CIDE firm in collaboration with the DAIP. The system was tested in May 2024 in 3 pilot establishments located in Abidjan, Bouak� and San Pedro. The tracer system is in an appropriation and generalization phase; the METFPA in charge of TVET has requested additional Technical Assistance for this purpose (MCC ANO in pending). Next steps include a circular Note to be signed by the METFPA Cabinet to validate the Tracer system. This indicator will therefore probably be collected during the October- December 2024 quarter (Q22)

title.narrative: TVET accreditation system developed

description.narrative: Date Output of According to Annex II of the M&E Plan, the development of the TVET accreditation system was expected to be completed in Year 4 of the Compact. The accreditation system for TVET centers is under development by SOFRECO in collaboration with the training supervisory unit of the TVET Ministry (METFPA) since July 2024. The system is currently being rolled out and socialized with key stakeholders by the METFPA . The next step is the issuance of a Circular Note by the METFPA Cabinet to approve the accreditation system. This indicator will therefore probably be collected during the October- December 2024 quarter (Q22)

title.narrative: Percent disbursed of educational facility construction, rehabilitation, and equipping contracts

description.narrative: Level Process of According to Annex II of the March 2023 M&E Plan, version N�2, 79% of the construction of the first and second phases must be completed by year 5 (July -23 to June -24) of the compact. To date, 26 construction and equipment contracts for all CDP have been signed. Based on the monitoring of the physical progress of constructions as of june 07 2024, the construction physical progress rate (data available for 29 CDPs) varies between 04.30% and 64.9%% with an overall average progress rate of 27.33% against 67.15% planned for the period.

title.narrative: Potential villages selected

description.narrative: Cumulative Process of This indicator is considered complete and is not expected to be updated further. Community mobilization activities resulted in the selection of 73 villages in which CDPs could be built. However, the MCA had to suspend the identification of villages that could potentially host CDPs. Indeed, due to budgetary constraints, the Compact no longer had the resources to build 74 CDPs as initially planned. As a result, it was no longer relevant to continue the selection of villages in which the CDPs were likely to be built.

title.narrative: School sites selected

description.narrative: Cumulative Process of This indicator is considered complete and is not expected to be updated further. Initially, the compact planned to select 74 sites for the construction of at least 74 CDPs. Community mobilization activities resulted in the selection of 58 CDP construction sites (78%). The target of 74 sites was not reached due to budgetary constraints. Indeed, the initial budget planned for the construction of the CDPs were insufficient to cover the construction costs proposed by the selected firms. As a result, MCA had to stop site selection activities as the available resources did not allow for the construction of CDPs on all identified sites.

title.narrative: Value disbursed of educational facility construction, rehabilitation, and equipping contracts

description.narrative: Cumulative Process of Disbursements were made to 11 constructions firms and 1 service firm during the period of Q20 and Q21. The discussion on 02/05/2024 between the M&E and Finance teams clarified the issue of exchange rates used in SAP. The system uses the exchange rate on the day of payment and automatically calculates gains or losses due to the variation of the exchange rate. The average exchange rate calculated at the begining of each period is only used for the revaluation of contracts denominated in XOF but not for payments. The negative value for the amount disbursed from the San Pedro region is explained by the fact that the CNTP firm had its contract terminated. The bank therefore proceeded to reimburse the guarantee fund for the construction work on the Oueoulo CDP.

title.narrative: TVET National Framework Activity

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR EMPLOYABILITY PROJECT - TVET National Framework Activity: The TVET Activity complements the Secondary Education Activity through a new TVET model that provides training to students in the skills and knowledge in-demand by the private sector. This new TVET model will be implemented through new and sustainable training centers developed and managed through a public-private partnership with industries in Cote d'Ivoire. This new model will be implemented with a goal of catalyzing a shift within the training system towards better identifying and meeting the training needs of the private sector. The TVET Activity is made up of two sub-activities designed to implement and support this new TVET model: A New Model for Private Sector-Led TVET Sub-Activity - The New Model for Private Sector-Led TVET Sub-Activity will introduce and test a new model of "Partnerships for Skills Development" ("Partenariat pour le D�veloppement des Comp�tences" or "PDC") to provide training through direct partnerships with the private sector; TVET Quality Management and Accountability Sub-Activity - This sub-activity will create primary tools for quality management and accountability to create the enabling environment for a long-term reorientation of the TVET system towards results-based management.
Abidjan
Abidjan
City in Gbeke Region
San-Pedro

usg:usg-activity.usg:purpose-statement: Cote d'Ivoire - EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR EMPLOYABILITY PROJECT - PROJECT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITY: This Activity support the other activities in the Education and Training for Employability Project.

title.narrative: Secondary Education Activity

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR EMPLOYABILITY PROJECT - Secondary Education Activity: The Activity aims to increase access to lower secondary education in two regions of Cote d'Ivoire and improve the access to, and quality of, secondary education and the governance of the sector. The Activity will be pursued through four sub-activities that will invest in new education infrastructure, expand and improve teacher training, reduce gender disparities in educational outcomes, and enhance the Government's information management system and use of such system for decision-making in the national education sector.
Gbeke Region
San-Pedro Region

condition.narrative: Further details on conditions precedent affecting this activity can be found in the top-level parent activities.

Prior to Disbursement of Program Funding for the Secondary Education Activity, the Government must have established an inter-ministerial teacher training committee with representatives from Ministry of Higher Education (including ENS), Ministry of National Eduction, Ministry of Economy and Finances, Ministry of Budget, and Ministry of Public Service, and the committee will have held its first meeting.

Prior to the Disbursement of Program Funding for equipment and materials for the ENS Abidjan campus or its practicum school, the ENS must adopt the new teacher training curriculum under the Teacher Training Sub-Activity.

Prior to the Disbursement of Program Funding for the Integrated EMIS, an inter-departmental committee will have been established within the Ministry of National Education to coordinate the Management Systems Sub-Activity and facilitate change management during the transition to the Integrated EMIS

The Activity will be pursued through four sub-activities that will invest in new education infrastructure, expand and improve teacher training, reduce gender disparities in educational outcomes, and enhance the Government's information management system and use of such system for decision-making in the national education sector.

usg:usg-activity.usg:purpose-statement: An Accountable Entity's, the Millennium Challenge Account (MCA) Cote d'Ivoire, costs for its Fiscal Agent, who is responsible for overseeing the accounting and funds control procedures for the Accountable Entity.

title.narrative: Transportation Project

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - Transportation Project: The Abidjan Transport Project will reduce transport costs and improve efficiencies for businesses by rehabilitating roads in and around the port area and improving road network management and maintenance.

title.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire Compact Key Performance Indicators

condition.narrative: Further details on conditions precedent affecting this activity can be found in the top-level parent activities.

"Prior to the Disbursement of Program Funding for the Transport Investments, the Government must have developed and adopted a plan acceptable to MCC to: (i) eliminate FER�s current debt by the end of the Compact Term; and (ii) define the reasonable prudential ratios FER must maintain in order to incur debt."

With respect to FER road maintenance, (i) prior to entry into force of the Compact, the Government must increase the fiscal allocation to FER by 20 per cent over the prior fiscal year�s total allocation of funding to FER, and (ii) thereafter during the Compact Term either (y) the Government propose and implement a plan acceptable to MCC for annual increases to the FER fiscal allocation or (z) implement at a minimum annual 10 per cent increases in the allocation to FER.

title.narrative: Transportation Project Results
Average annual daily traffic

description.narrative: Level Outcome of According to Annex II of the M&E Plan, data on the average annual daily traffic should be reported during Year 5 of the Compact. However, the road construction works have started in early 2023 (Compact Q16). The project team expects the end of those works in 2025. Data for this indicator will likely not be available until the final quarters of the Compact.

title.narrative: IRAP road safety rating

description.narrative: Level Outcome of After analyzing the reports and discussions with the ATP project team, it appears that the iRAP measurement on Boulevard de la Paix is consistent with the final, detailed design of the works on this section. However, for the Yopougon Expressway, some of the additional improvement measures proposed in the Safer Road Investment Plan (SRIP) were incorporated in the final, detailed design for the road, but the iRAP assessment was not updated to reflect these changes, which may have increased the safety ratings for certain categories of road users. For this reason, the percentage of the Yopougon Expressway that has an iRAP rating of at least 3 may be higher than what is reported for this indicator. In other words, for each disaggregation for the Yopougon Expressway, the data reported should be interpreted as follows: at least XX percentage of the road received an iRAP rating of at least 3. Finally, there are ongoing discussions at the project team level on the delineation of Boulevards Port, Vridi, and Petit-Bassam. Once those discussions have been finalized and a decision made, the MCA and MCC M&E teams will make a determination if and how to report the iRAP ratings for these road segments, which may require a revision of the M&E Plan. In September 2022, the GoCI and MCC agreed to officially modify the Compact agreement, significantly reducing the scope of the investments on the Boulevard VGE. As a result, the iRAP assessment completed in early 2022 no longer reflects the investments that will be completed by the Compact along the Boulevard VGE, which are now centered only on the Koumassi intersection.

comment.narrative: After analyzing the reports and discussions with the ATP project team, it appears that the iRAP measurement on Boulevard de la Paix is consistent with the final, detailed design of the works on this section. However, for the Yopougon Expressway, some of the additional improvement measures proposed in the Safer Road Investment Plan (SRIP) were incorporated in the final, detailed design for the road, but the iRAP assessment was not updated to reflect these changes, which may have increased the safety ratings for certain categories of road users. For this reason, the percentage of the Yopougon Expressway that has an iRAP rating of at least 3 may be higher than what is reported for this indicator. In other words, for each disaggregation for the Yopougon Expressway, the data reported should be interpreted as follows: at least XX percentage of the road received an iRAP rating of at least 3. Finally, there are ongoing discussions at the project team level on the delineation of Boulevards Port, Vridi, and Petit-Bassam. Once those discussions have been finalized and a decision made, the MCA and MCC M&E teams will make a determination if and how to report the iRAP ratings for these road segments, which may require a revision of the M&E Plan. In September 2022, the GoCI and MCC agreed to officially modify the Compact agreement, significantly reducing the scope of the investments on the Boulevard VGE. As a result, the iRAP assessment completed in early 2022 no longer reflects the investments that will be completed by the Compact along the Boulevard VGE, which are now centered only on the Koumassi intersection. Baseline

After analyzing the reports and discussions with the ATP project team, it appears that the iRAP measurement on Boulevard de la Paix is consistent with the final, detailed design of the works on this section. However, for the Yopougon Expressway, some of the additional improvement measures proposed in the Safer Road Investment Plan (SRIP) were incorporated in the final, detailed design for the road, but the iRAP assessment was not updated to reflect these changes, which may have increased the safety ratings for certain categories of road users. For this reason, the percentage of the Yopougon Expressway that has an iRAP rating of at least 3 may be higher than what is reported for this indicator. In other words, for each disaggregation for the Yopougon Expressway, the data reported should be interpreted as follows: at least XX percentage of the road received an iRAP rating of at least 3. Finally, there are ongoing discussions at the project team level on the delineation of Boulevards Port, Vridi, and Petit-Bassam. Once those discussions have been finalized and a decision made, the MCA and MCC M&E teams will make a determination if and how to report the iRAP ratings for these road segments, which may require a revision of the M&E Plan. In September 2022, the GoCI and MCC agreed to officially modify the Compact agreement, significantly reducing the scope of the investments on the Boulevard VGE. As a result, the iRAP assessment completed in early 2022 no longer reflects the investments that will be completed by the Compact along the Boulevard VGE, which are now centered only on the Koumassi intersection. Target

After analyzing the reports and discussions with the ATP project team, it appears that the iRAP measurement on Boulevard de la Paix is consistent with the final, detailed design of the works on this section. However, for the Yopougon Expressway, some of the additional improvement measures proposed in the Safer Road Investment Plan (SRIP) were incorporated in the final, detailed design for the road, but the iRAP assessment was not updated to reflect these changes, which may have increased the safety ratings for certain categories of road users. For this reason, the percentage of the Yopougon Expressway that has an iRAP rating of at least 3 may be higher than what is reported for this indicator. In other words, for each disaggregation for the Yopougon Expressway, the data reported should be interpreted as follows: at least XX percentage of the road received an iRAP rating of at least 3. Finally, there are ongoing discussions at the project team level on the delineation of Boulevards Port, Vridi, and Petit-Bassam. Once those discussions have been finalized and a decision made, the MCA and MCC M&E teams will make a determination if and how to report the iRAP ratings for these road segments, which may require a revision of the M&E Plan. In September 2022, the GoCI and MCC agreed to officially modify the Compact agreement, significantly reducing the scope of the investments on the Boulevard VGE. As a result, the iRAP assessment completed in early 2022 no longer reflects the investments that will be completed by the Compact along the Boulevard VGE, which are now centered only on the Koumassi intersection. description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of The jury met on September 18, 2023, with the participation of ENSEA, INP-HB, MCA-C�te d'Ivoire and Polytechnique Montr�al, and awarded the Master 3ES to 19 students from the first cohort including 3 women. One person from the first cohort did not pass the final exam and was given a second attempt to pass the exam. The 2nd cohort defended their master's thesis, but the 3rd cohort has yet to do so . The final jury, with the participation of ENSEA, INP-HB, MCA-C�te d'Ivoire and Polytechnique Montr�al, for the award of the Master 3ES will be conducted jointly for 2nd and 3rd cohorts. This indicator will therefore probably be collected during the October- December 2024 quarter (Q22)

title.narrative: Lane kilometers of roads completed in the District of Abidjan in accordance with the pavement preservation and safety prioritization investment list

description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of According to Annex II of the M&E Plan, data on this indicator should be reported during Year 5 of the Compact. But to date, the investment list for pavement preservation and safety prioritization for the district of Abidjan is not yet available. Following changes in the design of the ATP project, there are discussions about the relevance of carrying out this activity. It is therefore likely that this indicator will not be collected before the end of the compact. Ongoing discussions between the MCC and MCA project teams will provide further clarification on this situation.

title.narrative: Students participating in MCC-supported education activities

description.narrative: Cumulative Outcome of The first cohort of students began training on March 25, 2021 with 21 students including 3 women. The second cohort started courses on January 6, 2022 with 20 students including 4 women. The third cohort began classes on September 1, 2022. There are 23 students in this third cohort including 8 women. The call for applications for the recruitment of a fourth cohort has been launched and submission deadline was May 31, 2024. Selection panels will be set up in August - September 2024 to recruit and finalize the list of admitted candidates. This indicator will therefore probably be collected during the October- December 2024 quarter (Q22)

title.narrative: Amount of funding for road maintenance leveraged through the incentive matching fund

description.narrative: Cumulative Output of According to Annex II of the M&E Plan, reporting on the amount of funding invested in routine and periodic maintenance through the Road Maintenance Matching Fund was expected to start in Year 3 of the Compact, which ended in August 2022. Following changes in the design of the ATP project, there are discussions about the relevance of carrying out this sub-activity. It is therefore likely that this indicator will not be collected before the end of the compact. Ongoing discussions between the MCC and MCA project teams will provide further clarification on this situation.

title.narrative: Financial close for PPP for TPLC

description.narrative: Date Output of According to Annex II of the M&E Plan, the date of the Financial Agreement for a PPP for the TPLC should be reported in Year 2 of the Compact. To date, the Financial closing for a TPLC PPP has not yet been completed. According to the TPLC timeline, the financial closing for Atplc PPP will be completed post Compact. The AXELCIUM, GIDE, ARTELIA C�te d'Ivoire and ARTELIA Maroc consortium recruited in April 2022 as Transaction Advisor for the financing, construction, operation and maintenance of a TPLC under a PPP structure has completed the base period of its contract. During the Base Period, the Transaction Advisor has developped a feasibility study according to which the TPLC can go under a PPP. But the GoCI asked additional work so that the Optional period 1 of the contract activated on April 06, 2023 for a duration of 12 months has been extented to 18 months.

title.narrative: Increases in the fiscal allocation to FER

description.narrative: Level Output of In 2022, FER had effectively received an amount of 219.068 billion FCFA from the Government. This amount was 188.560 billion FCFA in 2021, i.e an increase of 16.2%.

title.narrative: Percentage reduction in the amount of debt contracted by FER

description.narrative: Level Output of The negative number reported for this indicator corresponds to an increase in FER's debt. At the Compact Entry into Force, the amount of debt FER owed to banks and contractors (outstanding accounts payable past 120 days) was 125.716 billion FCFA (including 110.593 billion FCFA for bank debts and 15.123 billion FCFA for contractor debts payable past 120 days). As of December 31, 2023, the amount of FER's debt was 310.249 billion FCFA, comprised entirely of bank debt and with contractor debts payable past 120 days having been reduced to zero as agreed with MCC. This represents an increase in FER's debt of 146.78%.

The negative number reported for this indicator corresponds to an increase in FER's debt. At the Compact Entry into Force, the amount of debt FER owed to banks and contractors (outstanding accounts payable past 120 days) was 125.716 billion FCFA (including 110.593 billion FCFA for bank debts and 15.123 billion FCFA for contractor debts payable past 120 days). As of December 31, 2023, the amount of FER's debt was 310.249 billion FCFA, comprised entirely of bank debt and with contractor debts payable past 120 days having been reduced to zero as agreed with MCC. This represents an increase in FER's debt of 146.78%. Actual

title.narrative: Road asset inventory database created for the District of Abidjan

description.narrative: Date Output of According to Annex II of the M&E Plan, the road asset inventory database for the district of Abidjan should be completed and available for use on January 31, 2022 (Year 3 - Q11). The development of the database is completed (Logiroad Deliverable 8 approved) but all of the relevant data is not yet integrated. The tool is still in the hands of the service provider and will be handed over to ageroute before December 31, 2024. A settlement agreement is being drawn up with the service provider with whom the contract has expired. This indicator will therefore probably be collected during the October- December 2024 quarter (Q22).

title.narrative: Road Users Associations participation on the FER board of directors

description.narrative: Level Output of FER provided the data and source documents during Q18. However, the signed attendance sheets and official meeting minutes of three different FER board meetings during compact Year 4 indicate that a Government official attended the respective FER board meetings in both their official capacity as a FER board member representing the Government and also acted as a proxy for a road user associations representative during those same meetings. There is nothing inherently problematic with having an individual serve as a proxy for a board member in instances where the board member is unavailable, and indeed there are specific statutes and decrees that provide for this. However, in light of the definition of this indicator � which measures the presence of road user associations � as well as the project logic result the indicator is designed to capture (i.e., �Improved road user oversight of FER�), it is not possible to count a Government official serving as proxy for a road user association when calculating the numerator for this indicator. This nuance will be clarified in the �Additional Information� column of the Compact M&E Plan during the next revision of the M&E Plan. When calculating this indicator for Compact Year 4 in line with what is outlined above, out of the seven meetings that were held during the year, one meeting (November 8, 2022) does not meet the minimum threshold for the presence of road user associations. Thus, the final value reported for this indicator for Compact Year 4 is 85.7%

title.narrative: Kilometers of roads under works contracts

description.narrative: Cumulative Process of To date, all road construction/rehabilitation contracts have been signed between MCA-C�te d'Ivoire and the contractors. There is no more data expected for this indicator until the end of the Compact. However, in comparison to the approved modification of the Abidjan Transport Project from September 2022, we note a difference between what is reported here (20.9 km) versus what was anticipated according to the modification of the project (24,6km). Given that all work contracts have been signed, the M&E team is working with the ATP project team to provide explanations for this 3.7 km gap.

title.narrative: Temporary employment generated in road construction

description.narrative: Cumulative Process of The temporary employment being counted under this indicator includes individuals working under limited term contracts (contrat � dur�e d�termin�e or CDD) and consultants. Individuals working under permanent contracts without a fixed end date (contrat � dur�e ind�termin�e or CDI), who thus will continue working for the construction firm beyond the end of this project, as well as interns are not counted under this indicator. The individual responsible for collecting, cleaning, and reporting data for this indicator to MCA M&E is on vacation and will not return until the end of August. It will likely not be possible to for MCA M&E to obtain the data and source documents and conduct the necessary verifications prior to submission of the Q22 QDRP for NO in early September. Thus, data for this indicator for Q21 will be reported as part of the QDRP to be submitted December 2024. If any corrections are required for the Q20 data, a HACR will be submitted in November 2024.

title.narrative: Value disbursed of road construction contracts

description.narrative: Cumulative Process of According to Annex II of the M&E plan, reporting on this indicator should have started in Year 2 of the Compact, which ended in August 2021 (Q9). However, due to delays linked to the COVID-19 pandemic and other factors, reporting on this indicator did not start until Q15. All the road construction/rehabilitation contracts have been signed between MCA-C�te d'Ivoire and the contractors. The discussion on 02/05/2024 between the M&E and Finance teams clarified the issue of exchange rates used in SAP. The system uses the exchange rate on the day of payment and automatically calculates gains or losses due to the variation of the exchange rate. The average exchange rate calculated at the begining of each period is only used for the revaluation of contracts denominated in XOF but not for payments.

title.narrative: Infrastructure Activity

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - Transportation Project - Infrastructure Activity: This Activity will focus on the rehabilitation of up to 32 kilometers of critical roadway and adjoining infrastructure in the central corridor of Abidjan to improve overall travel times, improve traffic movement through improved geometric alignment and signalization, improve road safety, and integrate multi-modal planning (coordination with alternative, corresponding or nearby transport systems), to reduce household transport costs and increase revenue for businesses.

MCC Funding will be used to rehabilitate an approximate 9 km, six-lane section (three (3) lanes in each direction, plus two two-lane service-lanes) from Felix Houphou�t-Boigny Bridge to Akwaba Intersection

BMCC Funding will be used to rehabilitate an approximate combined 8 km, four-lane section (two lanes in each direction) that consist of (i) from the Felix Houphou�t-Boigny Bridge to the Tri Postal Intersection and the Vridi Industrial Zone, (ii) from the Tri Postal Intersection to Bus N� 19 Terminal of the Boulevard to Vridi, (iii) the adjoining Boulevard de Petit Bassam roundabout, and (iv) the existing 100 meter bridge along the Vridi Canal.
MCC Funding will be used to rehabilitate an approximate 7 km section of the six-lane Boulevard de la Paix.
MCC Funding will be used to rehabilitate an approximate 8 km section of the six-lane Yopougon Expressway from Adjame Bridge/�Pont Ferrailles� and ending at the Gesco intersection.

condition.narrative: Further details on conditions precedent affecting this activity can be found in the top-level parent activities.

Prior to Disbursement of Program Funding for Transport Investments on Boulevard du Port, Boulevard de Vridi, and Boulevard de Petit Bassam, the Government must have made available the necessary land with clean or proper title, in or near the Port, but away from the Transport Infrastructure Activity, where trucks will be required to relocate for short-term Port parking, prior to works in each such zone, as determined necessary by MCC.

Prior to the Disbursement for construction works under the Road Maintenance Fund Sub-Activity, the private sector or road user participation on the board of directors of FER will have increased to a minimum of 50 per cent.

Prior to the Disbursement of Program Funding for a particular works or construction contract for the Abidjan Transport Project, MCA-C�te d'Ivoire must develop and implement a site-specific traffic management plan and the provision of other protections during construction in order to establish effective and safe separation between road users and the construction works during all phases of works and construction, and maintain or enhance traffic flows, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC

usg:usg-activity.usg:purpose-statement: Cote d'Ivoire - Transportation Project - Infrastructure Activity: This Activity will focus on the rehabilitation of up to 32 kilometers of critical roadway and adjoining infrastructure in the central corridor of Abidjan to improve overall travel times, improve traffic movement through improved geometric alignment and signalization, improve road safety, and integrate multi-modal planning (coordination with alternative, corresponding or nearby transport systems), to reduce household transport costs and increase revenue for businesses.

title.narrative: Transportation Management and Planning Activity

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - Transportation Project - Transportation Management and Planning Activity: The Activity will focus on building the technical and managerial capacity of the Government's road-transport related agencies through improved educational know-how and infrastructure asset-management techniques, which integrate the engineering, economics, environmental, and social elements and activities related to road design, preservation and maintenance. MCC Funding will support three inter-related sub-activities that (i) invest in educational and training resources for road asset management, (ii) develop road asset and safety resources and management tools, and (iii) improve the use of road maintenance funds. A fourth sub-activity will focus on helping the Government resolve the persistent problem of heavy-truck parking near and around the Port of Abidjan. The Compact will provide this support to and through Cote d'Ivoire's road-transport agencies.
Abidjan

title.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire-Due Diligence Fund

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire: Due Diligence funding is used to obtain sufficient information to evaluate, assess and appraise projects during program development, effectively oversee and monitor program implementation, conduct quality assurance, and then evaluate the results of the project once complete.

title.narrative: Agriculture Project

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - Agriculture Project: Due Diligence funding is used to obtain sufficient information to evaluate, assess and appraise projects during program development, effectively oversee and monitor program implementation, conduct quality assurance, and then evaluate the results of the project once complete. In this particular project, due diligence funds were used to hire external technical assistance to support MCC's assessment and oversight of the MCA's agriculture projects to ensure country-led designs and subsequent implementation were consistent with MCC guidance.

In this particular project, due diligence funds were used to hire external technical assistance to support MCC's assessment and oversight of the MCA's health sector project to ensure country-led designs and subsequent implementation were consistent with MCC guidance.

condition.narrative: Further details on conditions precedent affecting this activity can be found in the top-level parent activities.

title.narrative: Monitoring and Evaluation

description.narrative: Cote d'Ivoire - Monitoring and Evaluation project: Due Diligence funding is used to obtain sufficient information to evaluate, assess and appraise projects during program development, effectively oversee and monitor program implementation, conduct quality assurance, and then evaluate the results of the project once complete. In this particular project, due diligence funds were used to hire external technical assistance and/or collect data to support the design and implementation of the MCA's M&E and Economic Analysis frameworks, through compact implementation and evaluation stages.
